DataElement.preferredName: Melanoma Surgical Margin Circumferential Distance Measurement
DataElement.preferredDefinition: a value in millimeters indicating the measured length between a malignant lesion of atypical melanocytes and the nearest radial (or circumferential) border of tissue removed during cancer surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to the space between a malignant lesion composed of atypical, neoplastic melanocytes and the nearest radial (or circumferential) border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A malignant, usually aggressive tumor composed of atypical, neoplastic melanocytes that contain melanin.  Most often, melanomas arise in the skin (cutaneous melanomas) and include the following histologic subtypes: superficial spreading melanoma, nodular melanoma, acral lentiginous melanoma, and lentigo maligna melanoma.  Cutaneous melanomas may arise from acquired or congenital melanocytic or dysplastic nevi.  Melanomas may also arise in other anatomic sites including the gastrointestinal system, eye, urinary tract, and reproductive system.  Melanomas frequently metastasize to lymph nodes, liver, lungs, and brain. -- 2004:The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.

Concepts.definition: A malignant, usually aggressive tumor composed of atypical, neoplastic melanocytes. Most often, melanomas arise in the skin (cutaneous melanomas) and include the following histologic subtypes: superficial spreading melanoma, nodular melanoma, acral lentiginous melanoma, and lentigo maligna melanoma. Cutaneous melanomas may arise from acquired or congenital melanocytic or dysplastic nevi. Melanomas may also arise in other anatomic sites including the gastrointestinal system, eye, urinary tract, and reproductive system. Melanomas frequently metastasize to lymph nodes, liver, lungs, and brain.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Property.preferredDefinition: No value exists.:The space between two objects or points.

Concepts.definition: The space separating two objects or points.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements of a patient's surgical margins.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: a numeric value indicating the microscopically measured length or distance between a malignant lesion or tumor and a border of tissue removed during cancer surgery.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements of a patient's surgical margins.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Microscopic; too small to be seen except under a microscope.:Measurement; the size or magnitude of something.

Concepts.definition: Too small to be seen except under a microscope.
Annotation used to indicate the size or magnitude of something that was determined by comparison to a standard.
